By leveraging these solutions within a clean core environment, businesses can better understand their processes, identify root causes of issues more easily, and reduce both transformation time and risk outcomes that are far harder to achieve without a clean process core. Well-documented, efficient processes also help organizations remain competitive in a fast-paced business environment, ultimately leading to stronger results.

Clean Data: In the cloud and digital age, clean, usable data is one of the most valuable assets for organizations, enabling faster decision-making and actionable insights. Following a transformation to S4HANA Cloud, businesses gain a robust platform for managing, processing, and applying data effectively.

However, data is only as valuable as the processes and principles that ensure its cleanliness. The three main pillars of clean data are:

  • Accuracy: Data must reflect the true state of the business. Without proper validation rules, regular quality checks, and governance, inaccurate data can lead to faulty decisions, inefficient processes, and reduced user trust. Regular audits and automated checks help prevent these issues.
  • Completeness: Incomplete data undermines decision-making and trust. Businesses should enforce standardized data entry, validation processes, and comprehensive collection practices to maintain completeness.
  • Consistency: Data must be uniform across systems. Inconsistencies create confusion, errors, and inefficiencies. Maintaining standards, conducting profiling, and implementing integration and reconciliation processes are critical to consistency. [4]

Maintaining a clean core with respect to data maximizes the value derived from data, enhances process efficiency, and reduces total cost of ownership by enabling efficient management of data volumes and reliable results from business processes.

Conclusion

Regardless of the motivations for a transformation journey, maintaining a clean core during and after the process delivers significant organizational value. Beyond reducing total cost of ownership, a clean core enables the adoption of the latest innovations a critical advantage in the AI-driven era and provides the flexibility to meet evolving business objectives.

The five pillars of clean core represent more than a technological change; they signify a mindset and paradigm shift from on-premise to cloud-based systems. This shift affects custom code, data, processes, and overall business operations, keeping them effective and efficient.

When combined with a transformation initiative, a clean core unlocks a new operational paradigm, maximizing business potential and supporting the development of a sustainable, best-run enterprise. Given these combined benefits, it is clear that maintaining a clean core during a transformation journey is in the best interest of any organization.

References

[1]

"lemongrasscloud," April 2024. [Online]. Available: https://lemongrasscloud.com/articles/advantages-rise-with-sap/.

[2]

K. Bowman, "pathlock," March 2025. [Online]. Available: https://pathlock.com/blog/sap-ecc-vs-sap-s4hana/.

[3]

SAP, "SAP Leanix," [Online]. Available: https://www.leanix.net/en/wiki/tech-transformation/s4hana-greenfield-vs-brownfield-approach.

[4]

SAP, SAP Learning, [Online]. Available: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/managing-clean-core-for-sap-s-4hana-cloud.

[5]

SAP, May 2025. [Online]. Available: https://www.sap.com/resources/what-is-a-clean-core.

[6]

SAP, "SAP," 12 July 2023. [Online]. Available: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FZ8CYsNqhZU.

[7]

gsimeone, "SAP Community," [Online]. Available: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/what-is-sap-clean-core-with-a-sap-btp-strategy/ba-p/13561226.

[8]

B. Berkebile, "NTTDATA," [Online]. Available: https://nttdata-solutions.com/us/blog/sap-clean-core-strategy-what-you-need-to-know/.

entry.title: Building a RAG Bot on SAP BTP With Hana Cloud Vector Engine and AI Core
entry.content:
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) is a method for improving the output of large language models (LLMs). While LLMs are trained on vast amounts of data, they may lack access to proprietary or enterprise-specific information behind paywalls, or other custom data needed to generate accurate results. RAG supplements the LLM’s knowledge by retrieving relevant external information, making its outputs more accurate, relevant, and useful in a cost-effective way.

Key Challenges of LLMs Solved by RAG Bots

  • Presenting False Information: LLMs can hallucinate when they lack the correct answer, often providing inaccurate responses that may appear convincing, which can lead to wrong decisions.
  • Outdated Responses: LLMs are essentially prediction machines, generating answers based on their training data. As a result, they may provide outdated information if it falls beyond their knowledge cutoff.
  • Terminology Differences: Natural languages like English, Spanish, or French are subjective, and the same term can have multiple meanings. LLMs may misunderstand context, leading to incorrect answers.

RAG bots address these challenges by supplementing LLMs with relevant, up-to-date information, making them a cost-effective and reliable way to enhance AI outputs.

To complete this project we will need

  • Data not already accessible to the LLM: There’s no point in using widely known content, like Shakespeare’s plays, as the LLM likely already knows it.
  • A Vector Database: In this example, we’ll use SAP HANA Vector Engine. Many options exist, including AWS vector engines and open-source alternatives. choose the one that fits your needs.
  • A Python Environment: All code will be implemented in Python.
  • An Embedding Model: Here, we use OpenAI’s embedding model, but any freely available model from Hugging Face or similar sources works.

What is a vector database? why do i need it? how does it differ from a real database?

Vector databases store data as mathematical representations called embeddings. Imagine visiting an ice cream shop you’ve been to a hundred times. On your 101st visit, a super-intelligent shopkeeper could instantly guess your preferred flavor based on your previous questions. That’s similar to how a vector database works.

Each piece of data is stored as an embedding, and when you ask a question, it’s converted into an embedding as well. The database then finds the part of your data that is most similar to your query. For example, if your question is meant to return the number 6, and the 12th paragraph of the 200th PDF is embedded as 5.8989898, the database will return it because it’s the closest match.

It’s crucial to embed information carefully. Using inaccurate data or poor embedding methods can result in irrelevant or excessive information being retrieved.

What are embeddings?
An embedding is a vector representation of data generated by an embedding model. In our setup, the model creates embeddings for your data, which are then stored in the HANA vector database. When you ask a question, it is also converted into an embedding, and the database compares it against the stored embeddings to find the most relevant matches.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

What vector embeddings looks like

 

start:

For my data i used this . It is a long 2000 page pdf on aws lambda.

First install these dependencies in your terminal

python-dotenv==1.0.1 # For reading environment variables stored in .env file
langchain==0.2.2
langchain-community==0.2.3
unstructured==0.14.4 # Document loading
# onnxruntime==1.17.1 # chromadb dependency: on Mac use `conda install onnxruntime -c conda-forge`
# For Windows users, install Microsoft Visual C++ Build Tools first
# install onnxruntime before installing `chromadb`

Then import the following before proceeding

 

Step 1: Document Loading

At this point we have our database ready and we have set up our aicore model appropriately; now we can import our document.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Step 2: Splitting the documents

This is a crucial stage because how you split and chunk your documents directly affects the quality of results. Dividing documents into manageable segments allows the system to efficiently create accurate embeddings. When queried, these embeddings produce more precise responses.

Each chunk can also be enriched with metadata, such as page numbers or chapter titles. This helps locate the source if a deeper look is needed. Chunking must be done thoughtfully by headings, topics, or other logical divisions to ensure the system captures the content effectively.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Step 3: Connect to database:

At this stage, we are ready to generate the embeddings and connect them to our HANA database or any other vector database we choose to use.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

There are many resources on how to connect to hana, so for now i will leave this here.

Step 4: Access Embedding Model:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

As explained earlier, an embedding model transforms complex, high-dimensional data into numerical values that machines can easily understand. This makes the data easier to process and allows ML models to identify patterns and relationships.

A vector is a one-dimensional representation of data containing multiple values. For example, a weather vector might be [2, 32, 1000], representing rain (2 = yes), temperature (32°F), and location (1000 = a specific county). Vectors capture relevant information depending on the type of data being represented.

Since this is a text embedding model, it can only create embeddings for textual data. This is important if you want to embed image files etc.

Step 4: Adding Data into HANA.

First, create the schema. You can do this by running a SQL query with the desired schema. This schema will hold the table where all your embeddings are stored.

 

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

This code will create the table in your database, load your document, split it into chunks, and generate embeddings for each chunk.

When querying the data, your query is first transformed into an embedding and placed in the vector space. The vector database then returns the document chunks that are most similar to your query. This is why chunking is important: it ensures that the system can match your prompt accurately, typically using cosine similarity to find the closest matches.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

After integrating everything into a clean Streamlit UI, here is the final result.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Press enter or click to view image in full size

 

Thanks for reading.

entry.title: SAP Developer News August 28th, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION 

PODCAST:  https://podcast.opensap.info/sap-developers/2025/08/28/sap-developer-news-august-28th-2025/

SAP BTP ABAP Environment, release 2508

CHAPTER TITLES  

0:00 Intro 

0:10 SAP BTP ABAP Environment, release 2508 

1:38 SAP Open Source Webinar on Gardener 

2:34 Garden Update - SAP Community   

3:44 SAP Community Updates 

7:07 ABAP test cockpit 

 

TRANSCRIPTION

[Intro]This is the SAP Developer News for August the 28th, 2025.

[Rich]Hey friends, Rich Hallman here. I hope everyone is doing well. I'm now fully rusted from the Latin American Code Jam Roadshow. We had a great time and I'm really looking forward to seeing my new friends again soon. But for now, I want to take a minute and let you all know about the latest SAP BTP ABAP environment release, 2508, which just dropped last week. Nora Klemp from ABAP Product Management has posted a blog post outlining all of the new ABAP awesomeness for all of us to explore. ABAP Development Tools got a few updates, including behavior definitions for CDS table entities, a debugger comparison tool for internal tables, as well as other cool stuff. CDS got a new hierarchy generation wizard, which derives potential hierarchy nodes and guides you through the creation process. Fiori got some updates as well, including multi-dimensional reporting and multi-report applications. There are many more updates around business events, integration, reuse services, and much, much more. So check out Nora's blog post today for more information. Hope everyone is doing well, and I'll see you next time, friends. Bye for now.

[DJ]We wanted to just let you know about an upcoming SAP open source webinar on Gartner. Now, Gardner is SAP's open source solution for managing Kubernetes clusters at scale. And the project is now governed under the Neo-Nephos Foundation, which is part of the Linux Foundation Europe. Now, this is a move that really strengthens its long-term sustainability and aligns it with the EU's important projects of common European interest in the cloud infrastructure and services area. that's ipceicis the webinar is on the 24th of september open to all and we'll cover gardeners features see some recent developments and there'll also be some live demos the link to the webinar registration is in the description

[Tom]hi i'm coming to you here from my home garden building on the segment from DJ on Gardener. By home garden, though, I seem to have a problem. I can't get Kubernetes clusters to grow. But in all seriousness, bridging between the segment on Gardener, the open source project, and home gardening, I wanted to point you to a blog post on the SAP community by Marion Weiss sharing his home garden. Now, this isn't the normal SAP developer news segment where we talk about the latest in SAP tech trends. But it's still important because part of our efforts to reinvigorate the SAP community is bring more personality back to the community. So it's great to see Marion sharing his home garden. And we hope to do more initiatives like this and support them where we connect with one another, not just on technical topics, but other things of interest in our lives.

[Josh]Hey, everybody. Mr. Bluebeard, Josh Bentley. I am here as a community advocate to tell you we've been doing a lot of stuff in the community. So as you go through and look at the What's New section of the community, you can see updates and read about them. Jerry Janda even has put out the newsletter recently that he used to publish that actually tries to collate and make you aware of these things. So make sure you subscribe to that newsletter or check out this section of what's new on the SAP community. To that end, I think there's several updates that have been put in place from the actual feedback board that we launched. So if you go to the feedback list and you get involved in that discussion, this is where some of the changes are coming from. So please request more things be added here, dialogue about the things that are on that list. And that's how some of these improvements come to be. and then they make it into the what's new section a recent update that we did that's going to be a pilot until september 23rd is taking away the frames from the side of a blog post where we have a widget and we're going to remove that widget in that side frame and give you a little less white space and more uh content area to read your blog post so check that out see if you like it better let us know and in the blog post in Jerry you can see the compare and contrast of the two pictures that show you what it looks like with it and without it so that's one update that want to make you aware of another is giving more people badges we know you like getting badges in the sap community if you submit an answer or a post that gets a lot of thumbs up those kudos thumbs up likes they're going to give you badges now based on how many kudos that you get for your post so Jerry even references do you want to find out if you're a member of the 500 kudo club well there's a way to check that in the instructions that he post here in this blog post and also you could have a one, a 50, 100, 200, 500 likes, depending on how many people click that they like your post. So great gamification badges that are being awarded for that. And also we really want you to be active and give us good answers in the SAP community. And if you get a lot of accepted answers, we're going to recognize that. And so you're going to see that you are going to get retroactive likes and retroactive accepted answer badges assigned to your profile. So if You've got a lot of accepted answers and a lot of likes. You're going to get those badges assigned to your profile. So another thing, there's so much great information coming out about the community, is that we've actually gone through and we said, hey, it's hard to filter lists for events, and let's try to improve that. So we're adding geographic filtering, and we're also adding the ability to filter lists based on SAP managed tags and a few other features that people have asked for to be able to sort the events that are happening and make sure they don't miss something that they want to attend. so check that out as well as the final note in here which is about dark mode for those who want to actually switch and flip back and forth between dark mode and light mode we are turning on dark mode to the SAP community so if you'd like to compare and contrast that no pun intended but if you'd like to look at the contrasting look of dark mode check that out and you know what people sometimes call me papa smurf and i say that papa smurf had a white beard and blue skin so i'm dark mode papa smurf or maybe i'm light load papa smurf i'm not sure anyway check out dark mode let us know what you think there's lots of information lots of blog posts from Jerry I thank him so much for all the great writing he's been doing and putting out these updates and i hope that you enjoy your sap community it's here for you and we're listening thank you

[Mamikee]if you want to keep your systems clean and future ready it's all about using the ABAP test cockpit or ATC as a governance tool to support the Clean Core approach. The blog post by Olga shares how ATC can help enforce Clean Core principles, things like catching modifications that shouldn't be there, plugging non-release APIs, and making sure your extensions are safe when it comes time to upgrade. Now you can try out the new ATC checks for Clean Core to reduce the number of findings in your classic ABAP development and focus your adaption efforts on real technical depth. If you're building in the ABAP cloud world and want to stay ahead of the curve, this is definitely worth a read. Check the description below for the full blog post.

entry.title: ABAP AI - Chapter 2
entry.content:
Summary

  • New ABAP AI capabilities keep coming
  • Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities remain free of charge
  • Availability of ABAP AI in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition in release 2025 is ahead of us
  • ABAP AI will be available in older releases of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition as well, details and updates expected at TechEd.

In February 2025, we started the first chapter of ABAP AI and announced that Joule speaks ABAP. Now, it’s time to get ready for chapter 2!

In the past months, we have been delivering more Joule skills to speed up ABAP Cloud development, and we are now able to create RAP business objects – from the database table up to the UI service powered by generative AI. We can create unit tests, explain code, complete code in the editor, implement validations and determinations, and much more (see also our public slide deck). All these skills are part of the 2508 release of SAP BTP ABAP Environment and SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), and they will be included in the SAP Cloud ERP Private (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition) in the 2025 release. Please check out our updated tutorial on ABAP AI capabilities. In addition, we will continue to expand our AI scope and will deliver on the transformation aspect of our AI strategy. This starts with the 2025 delivery for SAP Cloud ERP Private, followed by AI capabilities in the custom code migration app in SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2602. Please visit our roadmap to keep track of our deliveries.

Let’s continue with commercials and keep it short: The free promotions we introduced at the beginning of the year have been extended until further notice! We are convinced that, in the current situation, we don’t want to put any commercial barriers on our offering and let all customers and partners benefit from AI-driven development. The corresponding material numbers for customers 8019124 and TDD partners 8019541 remain the same and can be ordered again. For those who started before the extension of the promotion, note that a re-ordering of the material is required. The procedure for the SAP BTP ABAP Environment and SAP Cloud ERP remains the same as well, and the initial blog post has been updated to reflect this, as well as SAP Note 3571857.
For SAP Cloud ERP Private, as of release 2025, the material numbers are also valid. However, the configuration will need to be done manually by you. Detailed information on this will follow.

But that is not enough. Will ABAP AI capabilities become available also for older releases of SAP Cloud ERP Private? Yes!
Imagine an ABAP AI service running side-by-side to your ABAP instance, providing full access to ABAP AI capabilities across hybrid landscapes. This includes SAP BTP ABAP Environment, SAP Cloud ERP, and SAP Cloud ERP Private. New AI innovations become available independently of release upgrades or support packages, allowing immediate leveraging.  Best of all, this ABAP AI service can also be connected to older releases of SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Sounds like a dream? Let’s find out – stay tuned for TechEd 2025 to receive all the news and updates!

entry.title: ABAP AI Revolution Accelerates: The ABAP Developer Who Built Enterprise Apps in Minutes
entry.content:
The ABAP AI revolution just got a massive functionality upgrade and stays FREE OF CHARGE for another year

Remember John, our seasoned ABAP developer who discovered the power of Joule for AI-assisted coding? His journey has taken an incredible turn. What started as relief from "quick questions" and real-time assistance has evolved into something he never imagined possible – building entire applications and transforming legacy systems through conversation in minutes. 

John's incredible journey is about to accelerate even further with game-changing news: Joule for Developers remains FREE OF CHARGE for another year – the promotion has been extended with no commercial barriers, allowing every customer and partner to benefit from AI-driven development through material numbers 8019124 (customers) and 8019541 (TDD partners). This offer is now available not only for the BTP ABAP environments (Steampunk) and SAP Cloud ERP Public, but also to our SAP Cloud ERP Private customers using the latest 2025 release version. For a deep dive in more commercial details see ABAP AI - Chapter 2 blog written by my colleague @AlexanderRother 

See John's ABAP AI complete evolution with 2505, 2508 and 2025 ABAP releases:

  • The Game-Changer: ABAP Cloud Application Generation
  • Intelligent Business Logic with RAP Business Logic Prediction
  • Seamless Integration with OData Consumption
  • Enhanced Extensibility with Extensibility AI Assistant for SAP Cloud ERP Public
  • The Migration Revolution: Custom Code Migration AI Assistant for SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025

 

The Game-Changer: ABAP Cloud Application Generation

John's latest project required a library application with multiple entities. Opening his package in ADT, he right-clicks and selects "Generate ABAP Repository Objects." The new OData UI Service from Scratch Wizard with Joule Chat appears.

"Create a library application with entities for branches, book stock, users and borrowing information. Generate the appropriate fields which fit the business case for the entities." John prompts.

Within seconds, Joule responds with a comprehensive proposal including all entities, fields, and relationships. One click on "Accept" and the wizard auto-populates all configuration fields. Minutes later, John has a complete, runnable RAP application with data model, behavior definitions, service bindings, and OData services ready for UI consumption.

Intelligent Business Logic with RAP Business Logic Prediction

But the magic doesn't stop at application generation. John's application needs sophisticated business logic – validations for booking dates, automatic stock calculations, and borrowing permission determinations.

Navigating to his behavior implementation class, John finds empty method stubs for his determinations and validations. The RAP Predict Business Logic capability kicks in, understanding the entity structure, field relationships, and business context to generate complete validation logic within the method implementation.

"It's not just generating code," John marvels. "It's understanding the business context and implementing proper RAP patterns automatically."

Seamless Integration with OData Consumption

When John needs to integrate with external booking services, he opens his service consumption model and starts the Joule chat with the /consume slash command. The OData consumption capability generates complete, ready-to-use ABAP code for consuming OData calls via the OData Client Proxy, tailored to his specific service model. 

What used to take hours of documentation reading now happens in seconds with Joule providing example prompts and OData request generation.

Enhanced Extensibility with Extensibility AI Assistant for SAP Cloud ERP Public

As business requirements evolve, the Extensibility AI Assistant guides John through adding custom fields for regulatory compliance. It assists him in:

  • Creating Custom Fields for borrowing information
  • Finding Business Contexts for the right extension points
  • Enabling Usages where custom fields can be exposed in UIs, APIs, and analytical views
  • Enabling Business Scenarios for data flow between business objects
  • Finding Value Help Views for code list-based custom fields
  • Finding BAdIs based on natural language input

The Migration Revolution: Custom Code Migration AI Assistant for SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025

With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 release, John faces his organization's biggest challenge: migrating 15 years of custom ECC code to SAP ERP Cloud Private 2025. The Custom Code Migration AI Assistant will transforms this experience (on October 2025 planned release).  These use cases are currently not available on the older releases, however the use cases delivered on 2025 versions will be soon provided also as part of the Custom Code Migration Application which is a standalone BTP ABAP environment (Steampunk) application which can connect freely to any ERP OnPrem or Cloud system to support RISE migrations. 

  • Using the Explain Capability: "Explain this legacy report," John types, selecting a 500-line ABAP program. The Explain capability provides detailed explanations of the ABAP program, breaking down complex concepts with support for ABAP classes, ABAP programs, and CDS artifacts. 
  • Explain ATC Findings Capability: When running ATC checks with S/4HANA readiness variants, John uses the Explain ATC Findings capability on his S/4HANA readiness findings. This capability provides detailed explanations and step by step resolution proposal on ATC findings from check variants for SAP S/4HANA Readiness, specifically for: S/4HANA: Field Length Extensions, S/4HANA: Search for Database Operations and S/4HANA: Search for Usages and Simplified Objects. Each finding links to simplification items, which Joule explains in detail.
  • Documentation Migration Assistance: Using the Custom Code Migration AI Assistant, John opens the Joule chat view,  type in /docs to start chatting about simplification items related to Custom Code Migration and ABAP SAP Help documentation.  To chat with the assistant about SAP S/4HANA simplification items and Custom Code Migration, just start asking topic-related questions. 
  • With Code proposal for code adaptation coming in SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS01, John will soon receive in addition of the step-by-step description of how to solve the ATC findings provided currently by ATC Explain functionality and a custom code adaptation automatically. 

The Complete ABAP Lifecycle Revolution

John's journey now encompasses the entire ABAP development and transformation lifecycle:

  • Build new cloud applications with OData UI Service from Scratch Wizard
  • Implement intelligent business logic with RAP Predict Business Logic
  • Integrate seamlessly with OData consumption
  • Extend dynamically with Extensibility AI Assistant in SAP Cloud ERP Public
  • Transform existing solutions with Custom Code Migration AI Assistant for RISE in SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025

John tells now to everyone: "Six months ago, I was struggling with syntax," John explains to his manager. "Today, I'm generating complete applications with the OData UI Service from Scratch Wizard, implementing business logic with RAP Predict Business Logic, consuming services with OData consumption, extending solutions with the Extensibility AI Assistant, and leading our S/4HANA migration with the Custom Code Migration AI Assistant – all through natural language conversations."

The impact is transformative:

  • Application Development: Dramatically faster with ABAP Cloud Application Generation
  • Business Logic Implementation: Massive reduction in development time
  • Migration Analysis: From weeks to hours using Custom Code Migration AI Assistant
  • OData Integration: Significantly less code required for side-by-side extension scenarios

 

The AI Revolution Accelerates – Chapter 2 Awaits! John's incredible transformation is just the beginning as we enter the next phase of ABAP AI evolution. Even more exciting, SAP is pioneering a revolutionary side-by-side ABAP AI service that will bring full AI capabilities to older SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition releases, enabling immediate access to new AI innovations without waiting for upgrades or support packages across hybrid landscapes. Get ready for TechEd 2025 where all the groundbreaking details of this hybrid AI service will be unveiled – the future of ABAP development is about to get even more transformative!

Ready to evolve your ABAP development approach? Check out the hands-on documentation in SAP Help and join the growing community redefining what's possible in enterprise development.

entry.title: SAP BTP ABAP Environment – Pre-Upgrade Option for Release 2511
entry.content:
Overview

Providing a significant number of new features is an important goal of release upgrades to deliver innovations to our customers and partners. There are four major release upgrades per year following a predefined schedule as described in this blog post.

An upgrade is intended as a “no event” for customers and partners. For example, only compatible changes of released objects (APIs) will be delivered. We recommend performing a test of the custom-built productive apps in a test environment for the new release. The complexity of the technical dependencies between the custom-built apps and the underlying environment cannot be tested isolated, only including the ABAP environment on SAP-side. Therefore, we offer you to pre-upgrade selected systems 29 days in advance to test the applications prior to the planned standard-upgrade.   

 

Purpose

This option enables a customer or partner to test the applications they have already developed on top of the new release a couple of days before the standard-upgrade. With SAP BTP ABAP Environment (aka "Steampunk"), we follow the approach of keeping released objects stable and provide all enhancements in a compatible fashion. Early testing is an additional measure to ensure proper software quality and might be used to detect unforeseen regressions. However, this option is not intended to test new features or to consume new features earlier.

 

Approach

The standard-upgrade of all systems to release 2511 is planned for November 15/16.

A customer or partner can nominate one or more already existing systems for the pre-upgrade. A nominated system will be upgraded on October 17 within a planned downtime from 8:00 to 16:00 CET. Depending on the system settings, the actual technical downtime might be only ~20 min within the mentioned timeframe. Please refer to this blog post about the downtime-optimized upgrade. 

We recommend nominating a non-development system, such as a test system. The nomination of a development system is technically also possible, but fixes or other changes must not be imported into another system with a lower release. The nomination of a productive system doesn’t make sense because the purpose of the pre-upgrade is the re-test of the existing application before the productive system gets the new release.

According to the approach explained above, this offer is only relevant for customers or partners having at least two systems.

There might be situations where a correction of custom objects needs to be deployed. Such corrections are possible if the development / correction system is on the older release and is imported into the pre-upgraded system with the higher release.

Except potential fixes, the pre-upgrade is based on the same version as the standard-upgrade. It is planned to perform the pre-upgrade based on hotfix collection 1. The pre-upgrade systems will get the import of hotfix collection 2 after 2 weeks in the middle of the entire pre-upgrade test phase. It is planned to perform the standard-upgrade based on hotfix collection 3 and import this hotfix collection 3 to the pre-upgrade systems on November 15/16 as well.

 

Costs

This offering is optional and free of any additional charges.

 

Planned New Features

The planned new features will be published on the What's New for SAP BTP ABAP Environment on October 17. This list gives you an overview of potential areas for re-testing. The purpose of the pre-upgrade is not to consume these features before the standard-upgrade, because the documentation on help.sap.com will be delivered later before the standard-upgrade. It would also not be possible to transport code of such an adoption, because subsequent systems are not yet on the new release during the pre-upgrade phase.

Independent of the upgrades of the SAP BTP ABAP Environment, we recommend developing automated tests for the custom-built apps to detect regressions early on and without manual effort for re-testing. Such automated tests are perfectly suited to be run in the pre-upgrade test phase.

 

Time Schedule

The following figure summarizes the general approach:

 

Milestones for release 2511:

  • September 16: Nomination of system(s) is possible in the Landscape Portal
  • October 17: Announcement of the planned new features
  • October 13: Pre-upgrade systems are known
  • October 17: Pre-upgrade (with hotfix collection 1)
  • October 31: Import of hotfix collection 2 into pre-upgrade systems
  • November 12: Potential decision to postpone the upgrade
  • November 15/16: Standard-upgrade (with hotfix collection 3)

 

System Nomination

To nominate a system, please register the system(s) by October 13 (EOB) latest by using the Landscape Portal. You can find further information about Accessing the Landscape Portal and about Register Systems for Pre-Upgrade. Please do not create customer tickets for system nomination like in previous pre-upgrades.

With such a nomination, the customer agrees to an extraordinary planned maintenance on October 17 (see above).

 

Report an Issue

Issues should be reported as part of the regression test phase by October 31 (EOB) to allow for a sufficient time frame for issue analysis and potential corrections on SAP-side.

Please create a customer ticket by using component BC-CP-ABA.

If a detected issue is likely to endanger the productive use after the standard-upgrade, you should use ticket priority very high despite the fact that the pre-upgrade system is not a productive system.

 

Exceptional Process in Case of Unresolved Priority Very High Issues

In case of the aligned decision on Wednesday, November 12 (based on unresolved priority very high tickets) to postpone the upgrade, a dedicated mitigation process needs to be started together with the respective customer or partner, with the following boundary conditions:

  • Resolving the open priority very high issues remains the highest priority for both, SAP and the customer or partner, as it is also the prerequisite for the upgrade.
  • According to the estimated issue resolution, catching up the upgrade needs to be planned.
  • The upgrade leads to a business downtime of 6 – 8 hours.
  • The upgrade must be scheduled within 7 calendar days the latest after fixing all remaining open priority very high issues.
  • We will not provide any fixes for the old release after the original date of the standard-upgrade to the new release.

In case business-critical issues are detected after the upgrade:

  • Issues need to be reported as priority very high issues and will be processed accordingly.
  • Going back to the release before upgrade is not an option. Therefore, resolving the issues in the new release with the appropriate priority is the required approach.

 

Summary

We recommend performing regression tests in pre-upgraded test systems to avoid day-1 impacts of productive custom apps after the standard-upgrade.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Table Maintenance Reimagined: Choosing the Right Framework
entry.content:
In this blog, we’ll explore a practical use case implemented in S/4HANA 2021 On-Premise, where we opted for Custom Business Objects (CBO) to enable table maintenance via Fiori with minimal development effort and also evaluate new frameworks to achieve this in latest S4/HANA release 2023.

Approach for choosing Custom Business Object (Decision Matrix)

CBO is based on BOPF framework which was widely used by SAP before the era of RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming), while this is still relevant, SAP has now moved to RAP based development and a new concept called custom business configuration, both will be covered later in context of data maintenance.

Why we didn’t choose RAP or Custom business configuration for this use case.
  1. Custom business configuration ( Business configuration maintenance object ) – This is available from S4 On-Prem 2022 onwards and the Fiori app for CUBCO is available after 2023 onwards.
  2. RESTful ABAP Programming – SAP has provided RAP Generator which can generate all the artefacts based on a table right from views, behavior definition , service binding , generation to Fiori app however this is also not available in On-Prem 2021, the other workaround could be to build all these artefacts manually and generate Fiori app which was going to take more development time, hence it was avoided.

Since we cannot go with above 2 options, the only 2 options left are SM30 and Custom Business object, as we want to move towards Fiori first approach, Custom business object was chosen as the Go to approach. Let us deep dive in this with the help of use- case and practical tips

What is Custom Business Object –

With the Custom Business Objects Fiori app, you can create and manage custom business objects. A custom business object is a hierarchical set of database tables with an API for creation, retrieval, update and deletion of data.

  • In The Fiori App ‘Custom Business Object’, a new BO has been defined and maintained as below.
  • User can choose what options do they want as part of framework, e,g, Change document, system admin date (last change at, created at etc are added by default).
  • User interface is disabled in this since it is only possible to enable if Embedded gateway is used which is not the case here.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

You are free to choose what kind of operations, out of CUD, should be supported in the BO out of box.

This is where all the fields are defined for BO.

Final Output –

Until this point, no coding has been done except for few changes in CDS Metadata for Fiori UI related cosmetic changes, all the operation are handled by framework out of box.

An additional button ‘Mass upload’ was added in metadata extension which is using intent-based navigation to navigate to another GUI application for mass upload of the entries.

Few Tips -
  1. Custom Table (Type Application) is auto generated in this case with Key field as UUID.
  2. Data entries maintained in one system cannot be transported to other system and must be maintained in target system, which was also the requirement in our use case.
  3. Once business object is published and moved to production, Deletion is not allowed.

How does the future look like for the same activity (Table Maintenance)-

As discussed above, there are 2 other ways to achieve this with minimal development efforts in new S4 HANA releases.

  1. Custom Business Configuration

    This is recommended approach going forward where a business configuration maintenance object serves as primary entry point for maintenance.
  • We have the option to use the Generate ABAP Repository Objects Wizard for Business configuration maintenance object to generate all required development objects based on a customizing table
  • Based on the Business configuration maintenance object, the custom business configurations app renders a Fiori element list report for the entities exposed by the service binding to maintain the configuration entries

Image courtesy - SAP

In short, Custom business configuration (Fiori app) is an umbrella under which all maintenance objects will be listed and serves as one stop shop while maintenance objects are the actual ABAP artefact which contains all the definition related to Object maintenance.

  • Different options like SM30 are available by default such Add copy action out of box.
  • Add Data Consistency Check for fields with fixed domain values or foreign key screen check.

All of the below objects are created by default including CDS view, service definition, service binding, business object maintenance , transport definition, implementation classes etc.

Final Output - 

Until this point, no coding has been done; all these features are provided out of the box by the framework.

The custom business configuration app shows all the maintenance objects for which the user is authorized.

Once the relevant maintenance object is selected, the Edit button would be enabled to allow creation, deletion, updation, etc. activities.

Few Practical Tips –
  • All tables must have a client key field and delivery class C
  • Have a timestamp field with data element ABP_LASTCHANGE_TSTMPL
  • To enable the "No Transport" option in the ADT wizard, implement SAP Note  https://me.sap.com/notes/3579012.
  • With few tweaks, it is possible to maintain data directly in production system instead of transporting. More details in this blog

As of version SAP S/4HANA release 2022, customers can use the generator for Business Configuration objects. The Custom Business Configurations SAP Fiori app is not yet available; app has been made available in release 2023.

2. RAP Generator 

Second approach to achieve this is using same generation wizard from context menu of table.

How is Custom business configuration different than plain RAP generator?
  • Custom business configuration is a framework which is also built on RAP artefacts, but it has other framework related functionalities (e.g change log for auditing) in comparison to plain RAP application.
  • Fiori for CBC can be accessed through generic custom business configuration app serving as single source of entry whereas RAP application should be exposed as standalone app.
  • Custom business configuration app is built only around customizing tables whereas RAP generator can be built around any customizing and application tables both.
  • CBC provides in built functionality to capture entries into transport request, but RAP generator requires explicit changes to incorporate transport feature.
How is Custom business configuration different than custom business object?
  • Custom business configuration is built on RAP framework (SAP recommended) whereas custom business objects is built on BOPF framework.
  • Custom business configuration has transport feature for data entries whereas custom business object does not any way to transport entries from one system to other system.
  • Custom business configuration is bottom-up approach where custom tables are defined first, and rest of the artifacts are generated around that whereas custom business object works on top-down approach where business object is created first then custom table is generated around BO.
  • Custom business configuration supports only OData V4 where CBO supports OData V2.
  • Custom business configuration app is built only around customizing tables whereas custom business object is built around application tables.
  • Once CBO has moved to production, it cannot be deleted.
  • In both the case, Metadata can be enhanced for any Fiori related UI changes, also additional validation, actions are supported in both.

Additional reading-

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/b5670aaaa2364a29935f40b16499972d/047e01c3bcdd4303a60b61364bd5b31d.html?locale=en-US&version=202310.002
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/custom-business-configuration/ba-p/13647767

entry.title: SAP BTP ABAP Environment on SAP Cloud Infrastructure
entry.content:
With the availability of SAP BTP ABAP Environment on SAP Cloud Infrastructure on September 19th 2025, Steampunk has reached the next milestone in the multi-hyperscaler availability for our customers, partners and SAP products using Steampunk.

The following region on SAP Cloud Infrastructure is now supported by SAP BTP and Steampunk:

  • Europe (Frankfurt) - EU access 

This new region complements the already existing regions on AWS, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud. Please find an overview about all supported hyperscalers and regions in the SAP Discovery Center.

The second region on SAP Cloud Infrastructure is planned in Q4/2025 in China (Shanghai). We will update and enhance the plan of further data centers regularly in the Roadmap Explorer.  

 

Available Service Plans

All well-established service plans standard, build-runtime, saas_oem, and free are available in the new region.

 

How to use Steampunk on SAP Cloud Infrastructure

To create a new Steampunk system on SAP Cloud Infrastructure, open the SAP BTP Cockpit and create (or use) a subaccount for the respective SAP Cloud Infrastructure region, for example, cf-eu01. Follow the steps as explained in the Steampunk documentation.

 

References

Please refer to the following additional references:

  • SAP Discovery Center for all supported providers, service plans and regions
  • Roadmap information for Steampunk infrastructure
  • SAP Community page for Steampunk

entry.title: How SAP’s ABAP Cloud Partner Reference App Simplifies Multi-Tenant Side-by-Side Extensions on BTP
entry.content:
The SAP BTP ABAP environment continues to unlock powerful opportunities for partners and developers seeking to extend and integrate with SAP Cloud ERP - particularly SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, by enabling SaaS extension development, leveraging existing ABAP expertise, and delivering benefits such as harmonized user experience, built-in product standard compliance, and simplified lifecycle management and operations out of the box. To further support this process, SAP offers the open-source ABAP Partner Reference Application as a best-practice resource.

The ABAP Partner Reference Application on SAP-Samples Git repository demonstrates how to design, build, and operate multi-tenant side-by-side applications using ABAP Cloud practices while following SAP’s recommended development approaches. The ABAP Partner Reference Application provides developers and technical architects with standard patterns, modular code, and documented guidance for building robust, multi-tenant ABAP applications on SAP BTP, fully integrated with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. It guides partners on designing, deploying, and extending ABAP solutions. It provides a blueprint for building scalable, multi-tenant apps that extend and integrate with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

 

What is the ABAP Partner Reference Application?

The ABAP Partner Reference Application (APRA) is a sample implementation that provides practical examples, such as the Music Festival Manager. It shows partners how to:

  • Build extensions on SAP BTP ABAP Cloud.
  • Integrate seamlessly with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Handle critical multi-tenant aspects such as tenant provisioning, onboarding, and isolation.
  • Follow SAP’s ABAP Cloud and Restful ABAP Programming Model (RAP) guidelines.

In short, it’s a real-world blueprint for partners who need a reference starting point.

Key Capabilities Highlighted

  • Multi-tenancy design: APRA showcases how to build applications that serve multiple tenants securely while keeping data isolated.
  • Tenant lifecycle management: Includes practical examples of provisioning and onboarding processes.
  • Integration patterns: Demonstrates how ABAP applications can consume SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs side by side, extending core business logic without modification.
  • Best practices in ABAP Cloud: Clean-core extensions, RAP-based services, and modular design patterns are applied throughout

Why It Matters for Partners

For partners building SAP-certified solutions, alignment with ABAP Cloud principles is no longer optional. APRA offers more than just example code: it provides implementation guidance to ensure solutions are cloud-ready, scalable, and compliant. By studying and adapting the repository, partners save time, reduce uncertainty, and can fast-track their certification and deployment processes.

  • The repository demonstrates and aligns with SAP clean-core architecture and RAP best practices, enabling maintainable, upgrade-safe solutions. Along with modularization, helping partners build solutions that are scalable, maintainable, and compliant with SAP’s cloud-first best practices.
  • It provides real-world samples for rapid development of side-by-side extensions in the SAP BTP ABAP environment.
  • It demonstrates end-to-end flows: business object modelling, onboarding and provisioning, secure multi-tenancy, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition API integration. It includes example business objects, tenant-specific onboarding logic, and detailed sample integrations with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs, serving as ready-to-adapt templates for real-world enterprise scenarios.
  • Each step—from tenant lifecycle management to extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition functionality using side-by-side applications—is implemented with guidance notes and sample ABAP artifacts, making cloud development approachable for teams at any skill level.
  • Multi-Tenancy Patterns: Learn how to isolate data and processes by tenant, automate provisioning, and secure user access using SAP BTP role collections and dedicated onboarding flows.
  • Integration Points: Discover how to consume core APIs, events, and data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition while preserving ERP clean core, using recommended SAP BTP services for authentication, navigation, and extensibility.
  • RAP and ABAP Cloud Usage: Access sample RAP service definitions and back-end logic that illustrate SAP’s latest cloud-based application paradigms, making it straightforward to adopt modern development models.

 Getting Started / How to Use the Repository

The repository is publicly available on GitHub and welcomes exploration. Developers can:

  • Import the Music Festival Manager application from your abapGit repository into your ABAP environment in ADT, browse the artifacts, and review the README for instructions on deployment and configuration to start with ready-to-run examples or tutorials.
  • Follow the incremental development guides in the main branch to build up your own ABAP partner app using the same best practices. Follow examples for multi-tenant design, onboarding, and integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Analyze business object definitions, RAP service implementations, and onboarding/integration logic to adapt for your own solution. Use the sample reference application as templates for partner apps, adapting the RAP artifacts and onboarding logic for your business scenario and leverage the documented guidance to use APRA as a starting template for your own solutions.

Inside the Repository: Packages and Artifacts

  • The repository is organized to guide developers through building a core ABAP application, then evolving it into a multi-tenant solution.
  • Artifacts are grouped by application logic (business objects), onboarding flows, integration APIs, and service definitions that illustrate SAP’s recommended RAP approach.
  • The samples Music Festival Manager and Poetry Slam Manager demonstrate business object modeling, UI integration, and tenant isolation in real-world use cases.

 How the Repository Accelerates Partner Solutions

  • Partners can reuse packages, study onboarding approaches, and adapt integration modules directly for their own certified offerings—streamlining time to market and improving solution quality.
  • Step-by-step documentation, real code, and sample data flows empower developers to master multi-tenant patterns and extend SAP Cloud systems with confidence.
  • The repository acts as a knowledge base and starter kit for enterprise ABAP cloud projects, bridging theory and practical implementation for SAP’s partner ecosystem.

By exploring this repository, developers and architects gain hands-on experience with the foundations of multi-tenant architecture, SAP BTP-managed security, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition integration—directly addressing the needs of modern cloud-native SAP applications.

For partners, the repository turns cloud-native theory into practice. Get hands on with SAP BTP ABAP Cloud, accelerate certified solution development, and leverage proven patterns for multi-tenant extensions—all with guided help from SAP’s own reference implementation.

entry.title: Validations in BOPF and Consistency Validation in BOPF
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

In this blog we will be going to learn about the Validations in BOPF.

What is Validation in BOPF? 

In BOPF, a validation is a consistency check defined on a node of the business object that ensures the data fulfills specific business rules before it is saved or processed. 

In BOPF, keeping the data clean and consistent is very important. Validations help achieve this by checking the data against specific rules. Just like determinations, validations are created on the node of the data model where they are needed. Today, we’ll walk you through how to create a validation and write the logic for it in the implementation class. 

Procedure  

Here we are defining a custom Travel table (zkk_dt_travel). 

@EndUserText.label : 'Data base table for Travel Details'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #EXTENSIBLE_ANY
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zkk_dt_travel {

  key client     : abap.clnt not null;
  key travel_id  : zkk_de_travel_id not null;
  key user_email : zkk_de_email not null;
  start_date     : dats;
  destination    : zkk_de_destination;
  status         : zkk_de_status;
  expense_type   : zkk_de_item_type;
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode : 'zkk_travel_hdr.curr_key'
  total_cost     : zkk_de_cost;
  curr_key       : zkk_de_cost_key;
  remarks        : zkk_de_remarks;
  created_by     : zkk_de_createdby;
  created_on     : datum;

}

The above table has the below shown data.

For the Database table we are defining the Basic view  

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZKK_DBV_TRAVEL'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Interface view for Travel details'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true


@ObjectModel:{
modelCategory: #BUSINESS_OBJECT,
compositionRoot: true,
transactionalProcessingEnabled: true,
writeActivePersistence: 'ZKK_dt_travel',

createEnabled: true,
updateEnabled: true,
deleteEnabled: true
}

@OData.publish: true
define view zi_kk_travel
  as select from zkk_dt_travel
{
  key travel_id,
      @ObjectModel.mandatory: true
  key user_email,
      start_date,
      destination,
      status,
      @ObjectModel.mandatory: true
      expense_type,
      @ObjectModel.mandatory: true
      total_cost,
      curr_key,
      remarks,
      created_by,
      created_on
}

For creating the Business object directly from the Eclipse editor, we have to make use of annotations which I have given with their functionality 

Here’s the explanation of each annotation in your snippet: 

@ObjectModel: { 
 modelCategory: #BUSINESS_OBJECT, 
 compositionRoot: true, 
 transactionalProcessingEnabled: true, 
 writeActivePersistence: 'ZKK_dt_travel', 
 
 createEnabled: true, 
 updateEnabled: true, 
 deleteEnabled: true 
} 
 Explanation 

modelCategory: #BUSINESS_OBJECT 

  • Declares that the CDS view represents a Business Object (BO). This means it can be used in BOPF to handle business logic and transactional operations. 

compositionRoot: true 

  • Defines this entity as the root node of the Business Object. Other nodes (child entities) can be linked to it via composition relationships. 

transactionalProcessingEnabled: true 

  • Enables transactional behavior (create, update, delete, save, rollback) for the entity, making it suitable for business object processing. 

writeActivePersistence: 'ZKK_dt_travel' 

  • Specifies the database table (ZKK_DT_TRAVEL) where the active (persisted) data of this entity is stored. 

createEnabled: true 

  • Allows the creation of new records in the entity. 

updateEnabled: true 

  • Allows modification of existing records. 

deleteEnabled: true 

  • Allows deletion of records. 

@odata.publish: true    turns your CDS view into an OData service provider, making its data available for consumption via OData protocols. 

In short: 

This annotation block is used to define a CDS entity as a Business Object root node with full CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) support and persistence in the custom table ZKK_DT_TRAVEL. 

Here I am creating the Metadata extension for the Basic view (ZI_KK_TRAVEL) for consuming it in the front end. 

@Metadata.layer: #CORE
@UI.headerInfo: {
    typeName: 'Travel',
    typeNamePlural: 'Travel Details'
}
annotate entity zi_kk_travel
    with 
{
@UI.facet: [{ 
id: 'Travel', 
purpose: #STANDARD, 
position: 10, 
label: 'Travel Details ', 
type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE 
} ]
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10, label: 'Travel Id' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 10 }]
    travel_id;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 20, label: 'Email' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 20 }]
    user_email;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 30, label: 'Travel Date' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 30 }]
    start_date;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 40, label: 'Destination' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 40 }]
    destination;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 50, label: 'Status' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 50 }]
    status;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 60, label: 'Expense Type' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 60 }]
    expense_type;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 65, label: 'Amount' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 65 }]
    total_cost;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 70, label: 'Currency' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 70 }]
    curr_key;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 80, label: 'Remarks for Expense' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 80 }]
    remarks;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 85, label: 'Created By' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 10 }]
    created_by;
 @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 90, label: 'Created Date' }]
 @UI.identification: [{ position: 90 }]
    created_on;   
}

 Now activate the Basic view and the meta data extension, when it gets activated the Business Object get created implicitly. 

Now open the BOBX Transaction. 

We can search the business object in Home business objects or click on the below marked option.

Provide the BO name which is our Basic View name (ZI_KK_TRAVEL) 

Now to Implement the validations expand the Node Elements  

Right Click on Validations will see the option to Create Validations 

Provide the Validation Name and Description and Class for implementing the validation logic. 

Double click on Class Name, and create a class which will be having the super class implicitly 

Now we have to provide Triggering conditions for the validations, so select the Node instance and tick on Create, Update, Delete and Check  

Save it and check and generate it. 

After this we have to go to eclipse and create a service definition on basic view (ZI_KK_TRAVEL) 

Now create a Service binding on top of Service definition and publish it  

When we preview it  

It will be navigated to the frontend while navigating it will ask for your SAP GUI Credentials to login.

Now go to SE91 Transaction and create a message class

Here, I am doing Validation for a Single status field only so i have passed only two messages  

Now I want to provide the Validations for Status field, so go to our class which we have created in Validations 

Implement our Custom login in this method.

  METHOD /bobf/if_frw_validation~execute.

    CLEAR : et_failed_key, eo_message.
    eo_message = /bobf/cl_frw_factory=>get_message( ).
    DATA : lt_data TYPE ztikk_travel,   " Table type for header node
           ls_msg  TYPE symsg.
    io_read->retrieve(
      EXPORTING
        iv_node                 = is_ctx-node_key
        it_key                  = it_key
        iv_fill_data            = abap_true
        it_requested_attributes = VALUE #(
                                          (                 zif_i_kk_travel_c=>sc_node_attribute-zi_kk_travel-status )
                                         ) )
      IMPORTING
        et_data                 = lt_data
    ).
    LOOP AT lt_data REFERENCE INTO DATA(ls_data).
      IF ls_data->status IS INITIAL .
        ls_msg-msgid = 'ZKK_MSG_BOPF'.
        ls_msg-msgno = '000'.
        ls_msg-msgty = 'E'.

        eo_message->add_message(
          is_msg       = ls_msg                 " Message that is to be added to the message object
          iv_node      = is_ctx-node_key            " Node to be used in the origin location
          iv_key       = ls_data->key            " Instance key to be used in the origin location
iv_attribute = zif_i_kk_travel_c=>sc_node_attribute-zi_kk_travel-status
          " Attribute to be used in the origin location
        ).

        INSERT VALUE #( key = ls_data->key ) INTO TABLE et_failed_key.
      ENDIF.

      DATA(lv_status) = to_upper( condense( ls_data->status ) ).
      IF lv_status NA 'ACCEPT' OR lv_status NA 'REJECT'.
        ls_msg-msgid = 'ZKK_MSG_BOPF'.
        ls_msg-msgno = '001'.
        ls_msg-msgty = 'E'.

        eo_message->add_message(
          is_msg       = ls_msg
          iv_node      = is_ctx-node_key
          iv_key       = ls_data->key
          iv_attribute = zif_i_kk_travel_c=>sc_node_attribute-zi_kk_travel-status
        ).

        INSERT VALUE #( key = ls_data->key ) INTO TABLE et_failed_key.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.

Now go to service binding and preview it. Try to create a new record. 

Here I am keeping Status field as empty so it will throw error. 

Now Status should accept only ‘ACCEPT’ or ‘REJECT’. If I try to give any other value it will throw error again. 

If you give the correct value ‘Accept’ or ‘Reject’. 

Conclusion

Validations in BOPF play a vital role in safeguarding data quality and enforcing business rules at the framework level. By defining validations directly on the business object nodes, we ensure that only consistent and compliant data enters the system, regardless of whether it originates from an SAP UI, an external interface, or a background process. This not only strengthens the reliability of the application but also reduces the need for redundant checks across different layers. In short, validations serve as a powerful and centralized mechanism to guarantee data integrity within the BOPF model.

entry.title: From Backlogs to Breakthroughs: What ABAP AI Means for Project Delivery
entry.content:
Hello everyone ! I am Shruthi, a Project Manager of BTP ABAP AI, and I am just about to celebrate my first anniversary with my team. Looking back at this past year, I feel so grateful for the people I work with, the projects we have delivered, and the way we have grown together. 

One thing I have noticed time and again is how small changes—like a new validation rule, a UI tweak, or a simple workflow adjustment—can have a huge impact for business users. But these “small” requests often take longer than expected because they get caught in processes and development backlogs. 

That is why the recent blogs on ABAP AI and the Extensibility Assistant really resonate with me. They show how SAP is already delivering tools that make development faster and extensibility safer. 

Key Highlights You Should Explore 

Here are some excellent resources that set the stage for this journey: 

  •  @Simona Marincei’s Blog: ABAP AI Revolution: Accelerates the ABAP Developer Who Built Enterprise Apps 
  • @GeorgWilhelm’s Blog :  Extensibility Assistant for Key Users: The Extensibility Expert Right Next to You 
  • @AlexanderRother’s Blog:  ABAP AI Chapter 2 
  •  Joule for Developers – YouTube Playlist 

Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities – Free and Ready to Use 

One of the most exciting developments for us right now is Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities. It is available for free usage today and brings AI-powered assistance directly into the hands of developers. 

With Joule for Developers, you can: 

  • Generate and refactor ABAP code with AI guidance. 
  • Explore sample data and learning materials. 
  • Speed up everyday development tasks and reduce repetitive work. 
  • Access tutorials and demos from the YouTube playlist. 
  • For teams like mine, this is a real enabler—it means we are not just talking about AI as the future, we are using it today to accelerate delivery and learn new ways of working. 

What We Are Experiencing 

In my role, I see these tools helping in very practical ways: 

  • Business users get changes rolled out more quickly. 
  • Developers focus on high-value, complex scenarios. 
  • Projects move forward with smoother coordination. 

The result is a stronger partnership between IT and the business, and a better experience for everyone involved. 

Final Thought 

  • ABAP AI today is already making a difference—it accelerates development, empowers key users, and ensures safe extensibility with built-in governance. And with Joule for Developers ABAP AI Capabilities now free to use, every developer has the chance to explore AI-powered assistance directly. 
  • For me and my team, this means more delivered outcomes, happier stakeholders, and projects that stay on track. 

As I celebrate one year with this fantastic team, I look forward to what the next chapter will bring. The journey of ABAP AI is still unfolding, and I am excited to see where it takes us.  

 I would love to hear your thoughts: how are you using ABAP AI in your projects, and what impact has it had so far?
